title: Jules Van Dievoet
text:
Jules Van Dievoet (, 7 March 18442 March 1917) was a <a href="Belgium">Belgian</a> jurist and <a href="Court%20of%20Cassation%20%28Belgium%29">Supreme Court</a> <a href="advocate">advocate</a>.
He was the son of <a href="Augustus%20Van%20Dievoet">Augustus Van Dievoet</a>, jurist, lawyer, historian and Latin writer.
Biography.
He married Marguerite <a href="Anspach%20family">Anspach</a> (18 September 185224 December 1934), daughter of <a href="Jules%20Anspach">Jules Anspach</a>, <a href="burgomaster">burgomaster</a> of <a href="City%20of%20Brussels">the City of Brussels</a>.
After studying at the Athénée de Bruxelles and studying at the Faculty of Law of the <a href="Universit%C3%A9%20libre%20de%20Bruxelles">Free University of Brussels</a>, where he obtained his <a href="doctorate">doctorate</a> in <a href="law">law</a> with distinction in 1865, he was destined for the career of a <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a>.
After an internship at Louis Leclercq, he was <a href="Oath">sworn in</a> as a lawyer on 18 August 1865. He was appointed <a href="barrister">barrister</a> at the <a href="Court%20of%20Cassation%20%28Belgium%29">Court of Cassation</a> by Royal Decree of 31 December 1880, replacing <a href="Auguste%20Orts">Auguste Orts</a>, who had died.
He was <a href="President%20%28corporate%20title%29">president</a> of the Bar of Cassation from 1900 to 1902.
